snippet: An appeals court panel found that N.C.A.A. rules violated antitrust law but struck down a federal judge’s solution that would have paid athletes $5,000 a year.
abstract: United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit finds that NCAA's amateurism rules are too restrictive, but strikes down compensation for athletes beyond cost of attendance; appellate ruling is partial victory for college sports establishment as it pushes back against efforts to expand athletes' rights.

byline.original: By MARC TRACY and BEN STRAUSS

lead_paragraph: An appeals court panel found that N.C.A.A. rules violated antitrust law but struck down a federal judge’s solution that would have paid athletes $5,000 a year.

headline.main: Court Strikes Down Payments to College Athletes
headline.print_headline: Victory for N.C.A.A. as Panel Strikes Down Pay for College Athletes
